Dear Ms. Edmon:
Attached is the Annual Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
February 10, 2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, MDHHS policy,
and Modified Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing
statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Nabiha Rizk, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
Employee Records
Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
One of twenty new employees did not have verification he/she
was free from communicable TB prior to employment.
Three of the six employee files were found to be
noncompliant with the tuberculosis screening. The three
existing employees had not completed the annual TB
screens.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report,03/24/2021, and
corresponding CAP, 03/30/2021. The facility must report
why the previous CAP was not successful.
Short Term
Rule 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(1) An initial health screening shall be completed for each
resident within 24 hours of admission to a facility.
Two of three youths did not have an initial health screening
within 24 hours of admission.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report,03/24/2021, and
corresponding CAP, 03/30/2021. The facility must report
why the previous CAP was not successful.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

• All employee performance evaluations need to have a date on the evaluation
showing when it was completed, have a date the employee and supervisor sign
off showing that the evaluation was reviewed and completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one substantiated incidents of maltreatment/ child abuse in care during
this licensing period.
SIR 2021C0207023 (07/20/2021). This was investigated by DCWL and DHHS. In this
case the staff member threatened to burn the youth’s stuffed animals, and staff
pushed youth against the wall by his neck. DHHS substantiated for maltreatment and
the facility was cited for the use of physical discipline. A CAP was submitted and
signed on 09/15/2021, noted violation for Rule 400.4158 (2) for using physical
discipline. In this case staff threatened to burn the youth stuffed animals and then
pushed him against the wall by his neck. The facility was also cited for Rule 400.4112
(4), the facility is in violation of the rule as the staff demonstrated an inability to
perform the duties of the position assigned. The involved staff was terminated, and
the facility implemented staff trainings for the use of physical discipline. The facility
has completed the CAP.
There was no incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted 19 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. This review period found the following
special investigations were completed and required CAPs.
 SIR 2021C0108034 (04/12/2021) This investigation cited Rule 109 (1)
Program Statement. Staff did not follow the agency’s policy that prohibits
6

staff from allowing youth to use their personal electronic devices. A CAP
was submitted on 05/05/21. The facility has completed the CAP.
 SIR 2021C0108037 (05/11/2021) This investigation cited Rule 157 (1)
Behavior management. Staff failed to utilize the behavior management de-
escalation techniques taught by the facility. Rather than ignore or defuse the
situation with the youth she escalated it by going back and forth with him. A
CAP was submitted on 05/26/2021. The facility has completed the CAP.
 SIR 2021C0219034 (04/26/2021). This investigation cited Rule 142 (1)
(a)Health services policies and procedures. Staff failed to take youth to the
hospital for exam regarding sexual behaviors. A CAP was submitted on
06/06/2021. The facility has completed the CAP.
 SIR 2021C0108045 (07/13/2021). This investigation cited Rule 2(f) the
agency policy pertaining to CPI training indicates there are ten modules
taught to all new youth specialist and staff was hired in February 2021and as
of July 2021 he had not completed the training. Additional findings Contract
the agency is required to have 1:4 ratio and they were out of ratio on
07/11/2021. A CAP was submitted on 08/10/2021. The facility has completed
the CAP.
 SIR 2021C0207024 (07/20/2021). This investigation cited Rule 127 (1) the
facility was out of ratio on 07/18/2021 and it was confirmed based on
documentation and reported by staff. A CAP was provided on 09/07/2021.
The facility was not complaint with the CAP resulting in a repeat rule violation
in October of 2021.
 SIR 2021C0207027 (08/18/2021). This investigation cited Rule 109 (1) (c),
youths are not allowed to leave their rooms until 10:30am and are sent to
their rooms around 6:30pm. A CAP was submitted on 10/18/2021. The
facility has completed the CAP.
 SIR 2022C0446001 (09/29/2021). This investigation cited contract
(individual and group therapy). The facility is in violation of the contract as
staff and youths interviewed acknowledged not receiving weekly individual
therapy from 09/10/2021 to 10/07/2021 as stated in the contract. A CAP was
submitted on 12/01/2021. The facility has completed the CAP.
 SIR 2022C0446002 (10/04/2021). This investigation cited Rule 127 (4) The
facility is in violation of the rule as it was determined that staff 3 was not
performing variable interval, eye-on checks of residents. Staff interviewed
reported he could not find the bedtime observation logs, and therefore there
was no documentation that variable interval eye-on checks of residents was
completed. A CAP was submitted on 11/22/2022. The facility has completed
the CAP.
 SIR 2022C0108003 (10/11/2021). This investigation cited Rule 126, there
was no supervisor on campus between 8 pm and 11pm on 10/10/2021 when
law enforcement located youth and contacted off duty supervisor. A CAP
was submitted on 11/12/2021. The CAP is being actively monitored and
thus far, the facility is compliant.
 SIR 2022C0108004 (11/04/2021). This investigation cited Rule 407 (1) (e)
there was substantial amount of black grim/mildew on the bathroom walls,
7

shower door, and floor in Juhnke Cottage. This investigation also cited Rule
142 (1) the youth electronic medication log indicates he did not receive his 8
am doses of concerta on 11/01/2021 and 11/02/2021. A CAP was submitted
on 11/29/2021. The Facility was not found complaint with the CAP, as there
were two additional investigations in December 2021 for medication
dispensing due to the nurse resigning.
 SIR 2022C0207003 (10/11/2021). This investigation cited Rule 126
Sufficiency of Staff, there are not always sufficient staff to provide for the
needs, protection, and supervision of residents. In this case, a youth was
supposed to have supervised visits, but the facility did not supervise at least
two of his visits. This investigation also cited Rule 127 (1) Staff to resident
ratio, on 10/09/21, the facility was out of ratio. Staff reported this, and the
staff schedule provided by the administration showed them to be out of ratio.
A CAP was submitted on 12/20/2021. The CAP is being actively monitored
and thus far, the facility is compliant based on interviews with youths, staff,
and review of schedules.
 SIR 2022C0207005 (10/25/2021). This investigation cited Rule 126
Sufficiency of Staff, a youth has an established safety plan that includes
direct line of sight supervision, but the facility did not ensure a staff was
present to monitor him from the bus on the day of the FCW visit. This
investigation also cited Rule 127 (1) Staff to resident ratio, staff reported to
be alone with five youth on the day of this incident. This is supported by the
internal investigation notes which additionally noted that there were two staff
with nine residents the morning of this incident when the facility ratio is one
staff per four residents. A CAP was submitted on 12/15/2021. The CAP is
being actively monitored and thus far, the facility is compliant based on
interviews with youths, staff, and review of schedules.
 SIR 2022C0207007 (11/16/2021). This investigation cited Rule 142 (1) (a)
(e), A review of the medication administration records, showed that staff did
not document administering medication C on November 13th, 14th, or 16th,
as those entries were left blank. A CAP was submitted on 02/18/2022. A
nurse was hired in January 2022 and has implemented a new process for
filling prescriptions, dispensing medication, and documenting medication
dispensing. The CAP is being actively monitored and thus far, the facility is
compliant.
 SIR 2022C0207011 (12/03/2021). This investigation cited Rule 159 (1), (3),
(c) Resident Restraint. A youth was restrained by staff and held on the floor,
which is not permissible within the facility restraint model, CPI. This floor
restraint was reported by the youth, staff, and the Supervisor. Additionally,
the staff put a shirt in the youth which is not a CPI technique Staff did not
document that physical management was used. Additionally, Staff and the
Supervisor did not write incident reports for this situation. Documentation of
physical management in incident report, and submission of incident reports
by all involved/witnessing staff is outlined in the facility policy. A CAP was
submitted on 02/18/2022. Monthly visits have occurred, and youths
interviewed have reported there has been no physical management by staff
8

The CAP will continue to be actively monitored and thus far, the facility is
compliant.
 SIR 2022C0446011 (12/07/2021). This investigation cited Rule 128 (1) (a)
Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training. The staff did not complete
new hire training within the first 30 days as stated in facility’s policy for
professional development and department expectations for new hire. A CAP
was submitted on 02/02/2022. The facility has been found in compliance with
rule and CAP as all the staff are current on their training.
 SIR 2022C0108005 (11/17/2021). This investigation cited Rule 109 (1) (c)
Program Statement. The program statement for Methodist’s shelter indicates
“Youth identified as needing intensive psychiatric care are not eligible for
admission.” Although the youth still required intensive psychiatric care at the
time of his admission to the shelter, Methodist accepted him aware that he
had just spent two months in a psychiatric hospital. The shelter program
statement also indicates “Youth with histories of AWOL may not be
appropriate.” The two youths both had histories of AWOLing from other
facilities prior to their placement at Methodist’s shelter. Furthermore, at the
time of this incident both boys had already gone AWOL from the facility at
least eleven times. This investigation also cited Rule 104 (2) Rules
compliance. The licensing terms for Methodist’s short-term shelter program
is males ages 13 – 17. The two youths were age 11 when admitted, which is
noncompliant with the terms of their license. A first provisional license was
implemented after this investigation, SIR 2022C0207012, and SIR
2022C0207014. A CAP was submitted on 01/26/2022. The facility has
closed the shelter and has not accept youths outside the terms of their
program statement. This CAP is being actively monitored and thus far, the
facility is compliant.
 SIR 2022C0207012 (12/07/2021) This investigation cited Rule 142 (1) (e)
Health services, policies, and procedures. Documentation clearly shows that
the youth was not getting his medication as prescribed and did not have all
of his prescribed medications available. There was a lack of oversight of this
process evidenced by the staff not documenting dispensing on numerous
entries on the MARs and no one addressing the omissions. Additionally, the
lack of oversight is evidenced by the staff noting the medication was out on
the MARs and in the daily log and no one above the staff level ensuring that
the situation was remedied in a timely manner. They were also cited for Rule
407 Facility and premises maintenance. The bathroom floor did have a large
hole and floor tiles were loose, creating multiple hazards. A first provisional
license was implemented after this investigation, SIR 2022C0108005, and
SIR 2022C0207014. A CAP was submitted on 03/02/2022. A nurse was
hired in January 2022 and has been trained, and have implemented a new
process for filling prescriptions, dispensing medication, and documenting
medication dispensing. This CAP is being actively monitored during the
monthly visits and thus far, the facility is compliant.
 SIR 2022C0207014 (12/21/2021). This investigation cited Rule 142 (1) (e)
(g) Health services policies and procedures. Documentation provided by the
9

facility, for two youths, showed that not all medications were dispensed as
prescribed. It also appears that the facility did not ensure that all medications
were provided for the youth for a home pass, based on the emails
exchanged between the mother and the facility. Medication dispensing
issues have been found repeatedly over the past few months, while the
facility was in transition with nurses, so it is critical that the facility
administration ensure oversight to this process to avoid further violations.
Although this was a repeat violation for a medication dispensing, additional
adverse licensing action was not recommended due to the overlapping
timeframe of the repeat violation, the recent date for approval of the previous
CAP, as well as the recent change in Chief Administrator and Director. A
CAP was submitted 02/21/2022. A nurse was hired in January, trained, and
have implemented a new process for filling prescriptions, dispensing
medication, and documenting medication dispensing. This CAP is being
actively monitored during the monthly visits and thus far, the facility is
compliant.
During this period the facility was struggling due to staffing issues, change in
administrator and director, nurse resigning, and operating the shelter. There was an
increase in the number of complaints with several repeated rule violations for staff
sufficiency and medication refill and dispensing. During this reporting period the
facility had an increased number of AWOLs from their shelter and were cited for
accepting youths outside the terms of their licensing. This resulted in the facility being
put on a first provisional. There was overlapping timeframe for the repeat violation
and the date for approval of the previous CAP. The facility has closed the shelter.
The facility hired a nurse in January 2022 and is in the process of hiring a second
nurse to ensure compliance with the rule and CAP regarding medication dispensing
and refill. The nurse was interviewed and provide a detailed report of the new
process for refiling, dispensing, and documentation of medication. Staff and youths
were interviewed and reported no current issues with sufficiency of staff and
maintaining ratio.
Monthly visits have been occurring and the facility is working on implementing the
CAPs and ensuring compliance. They are focusing on maintaining ratio, medication
refill and dispensing, staff supervision, staff training, and following facility policies.
The facility is currently fully staffed and are in ratio. They are also working with the
Residential Collaboration and Technical Assistance Unit (RCTAU) on an action plan
developed to address challenges the agency was struggling with this reporting
period.
This inspection report outlines four violations, with two being repeat violations for TB
testing and initial health screen within 24 hours of admission. There were two rule
violations for ISP and USP not being signed by social service worker and supervisor,
which was prior to the new Clinical Director being hired. He is working with the clinical
team to ensuring compliance with therapy and documentation. During this reporting
period there were only 8 restraints compared to last year they had 42. A walk through
10

was completed and all the cottages were found to be clean, neat, and no safety
concerns. There will be ongoing monthly visits to monitor CAPs follow up to ensure
compliance.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy and a
corrective action plan is required. The facility was issued a first provisional license
after the date of this inspection, but prior to the report being issued. Therefore, this
report is not for license renewal. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan,
the agency will remain on a First Provisional License.
